commits.message: Add 31 boxes of potential hacktivity output

issue.title: Suggest: max-age=0 or no Cache-Control header by default
issue.body:
1. It is what `express` and `nginx` do
2. If user forget `-c-1`, and visited a page by mobile phone, they must restart `http-server` and manually clean phone cache. (I always forget this, almost use `http-server` as local dev server)

comment.body:
Yeah...I keep pondering this also. Our current "tagline" though is "a simple zero-configuration command-line http server."

Perhaps if file-based configuration is available, but not the default, we can have both things in one package.

Pondering. ðŸ˜ƒ

issue.title: Can I run the server programmatically ?
issue.body:
Is it possible to require this module and start the server form my code ? i really need to do it that way, how shall I proceed ?

Thanks

commits.message: Add npm run serve for doing jekyll serving

issue.title: Support HTTP PUT requests via a flag
issue.body: It would be super useful for making local web apps that can also write files.

comment.body: @yura-pakhuchiy could you file another issue for that? I'm not sure what the expected behavior here would be, so explaining that would be ideal. Thanks!

issue.title: Suggest: max-age=0 or no Cache-Control header by default
issue.body:
1. It is what `express` and `nginx` do
2. If user forget `-c-1`, and visited a page by mobile phone, they must restart `http-server` and manually clean phone cache. (I always forget this, almost use `http-server` as local dev server)

comment.body: I too often forget the `-c-1` bit. However, I think changing this default would at least mean we'd need a major point release to avoid breaking deployments that depend on the current defaults.

issue.title: make http-server extensible through plugins
issue.body:
this change brings:
- events to http-server
- extensibility via plugins
- externalization of existing functionality into plugins
  - http-server-cors
  - http-server-logger
  - http-server-robots
- a missing test for `options.logFn`

commits.message: Remove artifact from Code of Conduct file

Move 2016 celebrants into archive file; update

issue.title: Build a highlighter
issue.body:
This does eek into the realm of UX, so I want to proceed cautiously here. However, juggling the "mixed tree" environment discussed in #21 is likely to be a near everyday occurrence for folks building annotation tools.

If we can collectively solve that issue well, we'll all win. ðŸ˜

comment.body: Additionally, this might help inform things the browsers need to change/tweak/add about how the DOM itself works and interacts.

issue.title: Ability to use multiple layers of annotation.
issue.body:
This kind of thing cannot be represented in a DOM easily, unless we have a tree and a way for each tree to just represent the index of the annotations in it.

Working in a DOM:
<annotation type="important_sentence">The <annotation type="animal">cat</annotation> is on the <annotation type="place">roof</annotation></annotation> 

Not working in a DOM:
 <anno1>.....<anno2>.....</anno1>.....</anno2>   

I was envisionning something similar to (not following any W3C recommendation here, just an idea)
<text>
Something is here
<annotations>
<annotation_layer><annotation type="verb" start_index="9" end_index="11">is</annotation></annotation_layer>
<annotation_layer><annotation type="sentence" start_index="0" end_index="-1">Something is here</annotation></annotation_layer>
<annotation_layer><annotation type="beginning" start_index="0" end_index="11">Something is</annotation></annotation_layer>
<annotation_layer><annotation type="end" start_index="9" end_index="15">is here</annotation></annotation_layer>
</annotations>
</text>

But copying the text over and over is probably not a good ideaâ€¦

comment.body: I think let's leave it open and begin planning/coding a highlighter. It's a super hard piece of this puzzle, and having that done will mean more annotation tools (built on Apache Annotator ta boot!). ðŸ˜‰

issue.title: Make `asf-site` the new `master`?
issue.body:
Right now the default git branch is `master`. The site, however, is published out of `asf-site`.

Do we want to:
a) use `asf-site` as our "prod" style branch (merge `master` into `asf-site` when it's "ready")
b) drop `master` and make `asf-site` the new default branch (everything else branches out of it)

I personally like option b. best, but a. can work too--as long as we make that clear and work it that way.

Thoughts? @apache/annotator-committers ?

comment.body: Ah. Seems you're right. ðŸ‘ to deleting `master`...which I think Infra needs to do. Correct @Humbedooh?
